Comment: [https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aJllQ9d3pYM](https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=aJllQ9d3pYM)  2010 speech at Google. The question asked by the interviewer starts at 31:30 and that clip takes place at 33:47.   She was being asked about her concerns over online privacy and how she (as DA) addresses that vs. another candidate.  I don't see how this is being taken out of context, as I don't think her explanation is incorrect? The only part I could really see is where she says the cloud is "above us" while pointing up, even though she immediately follows up by saying it's not in a physical location. If the confusion is "well the cloud is physical because it's made up of servers which are physical," well I believe they are confusing "cloud servers" with  "*the* cloud," the latter of which she was referring to
Author: Difficult_Network745

Author: Difficult_Network745

Comment: That is true, but "the cloud" specifically references the information that is accessible without needing to be there physically. The physical server (located in a data center usually) that runs the cloud is called a "cloud server"
Author: Difficult_Network745

Comment: You're doing politician speak. She said it's not physical, but that's mistaken. Understandable mistake for a layman but probably a public official shouldn't speak authoratively on a subject they know little of.
Author: PrimalForceMeddler

Comment: "The cloud" = stuff accessible via the internet. YouTube is part of the cloud (not a physical place)  "Cloud server(s)" = the computer(s) that has the stuff downloaded so you can access it via the internet (physical place)
Author: Difficult_Network745

Comment: She’s correct though. “The cloud” refers to the networked communications between servers.   https://www.britannica.com/technology/cloud-computing  No offense but it’s really silly to get upset at her about this. Feels weird and nitpicky for no important reason
Author: [deleted]
